title: 107_s622
content: The Act titled "Medicare, Medicaid, and MCH Tobacco Cessation Promotion Act of 2001" allows Medicare coverage for counseling to help individuals quit tobacco use. The Act allows Medicare coverage for counseling to help individuals quit tobacco use, including counseling for cessation of tobacco use as a new service described in the Social Security Act. The term 'counseling for cessation of tobacco use' refers to diagnostic, therapy, and counseling services for individuals with a history of tobacco use, provided by a physician or other authorized healthcare professional as covered under Medicare. Payment and elimination of coinsurance for counseling for cessation of tobacco use under the Social Security Act are amended to include coverage for drugs or biologicals that are otherwise covered. The Social Security Act is amended to provide 100 percent coverage for counseling for tobacco cessation, eliminating coinsurance and deductibles for outpatient hospital settings. The Social Security Act is amended to provide full coverage for tobacco cessation counseling in outpatient hospital settings, with no deductible applying to these services. The amendments will be effective one year after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 3. PROMOTING CESSATION OF TOBACCO USE UNDER THE MEDICAID PROGRAM. Promoting tobacco cessation under the Medicaid program by dropping exceptions for tobacco cessation medications and requiring coverage of counseling services for pregnant women. The text discusses the inclusion of counseling for tobacco cessation in medical assistance for pregnant women under the Medicaid program, with amendments to remove cost-sharing for these services. The effective date for these changes is one year after the enactment of the Act. The amendment to the Social Security Act promotes tobacco cessation counseling and medications as part of maternal and child health services under the Medicaid program, effective one year after the enactment of the Act.
